trial_identification.studytitle: Can a multimedia mobile phone programme help young people stop smoking?
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised controlled trial to determine if a multimedia mobile phone programme can help young people to stop smoking

interventions.interventions: A randomised controlled trial in young smokers who wish to quit. The intervention group will receive an intensive multimedia smoking cessation programme delivered via mobile phone (such as daily video clips, SMS of quitting tips). The duration of both programmes is 6 months.
interventions.comparator: The control group will receive a less intensive (e.g. weekly) study-related multimedia programme delivered via mobile phone.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Cost per quitter and satisfaction with programme

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Resident in Auckland New Zealand, current smokers wanting to quit.

trial_design.sequence: dynamic random allocation with stratified minimisation by age, ethnic group, level of dependence

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: Clinical Trials Research Unit, University of Auckland
sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Morrin & Mertons Rds, Glen Innes, Private Bag 92019, Auckland, New Zealand

fundingsource.fundingname: Health Research Council of New Zealand
fundingsource.fundingaddress: 110 Stanley St, Auckland, PO Box 5541, Wellesley St, Auckland, New Zealand

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study will determine if a multimedia mobile phone smoking cessation programme can help young people to stop smoking, in comparison with a control programme also delivered via mobile phone.
ethicsAndSummary.publication: Whittaker R et al. STUB IT: randomised controlled trial of a theory-based video messaging mobile phone smoking cessation intervention. J Med Internet Res 2011, doi:10.2196/jmir.1553 http://dx.doi.org/10.2196/jmir.1553 Whittaker R et al. A multimedia mobile phone-based youth smoking cessation intervention: findings from content development and piloting studies. Journal of Medical Internet Research 2008; 10 (5):e49. doi:10.2196/jmir.1007.
